sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:

  • Bacteremia: 25,000 to 30,000 units/kg/day IM divided every 4 to 6 hours; not routinely recommended due to pain at injection site
  • Bacterial infection of eye: Neosporin(R) solution, 1 to 2 drops into affected eye(s) every 4 hours for 7 to 10 days; dosage may be increased to 2 drops every hour in severe infections
  • Bacterial infection of eye: Neosporin(R) ointment, apply to affected eye(s) every 3 to 4 hours for 7 to 10 days
  • Bacterial infection of eye: injection, instill 1 to 3 drops of a 0.1% to 0.25% solution (10,000 to 25,000 units/mL) OPHTHALMICALLY into affected eye(s) every hour; increase intervals as response indicates; MAX 25,000 units/kg/day

  • Irrigation of urinary bladder; Adjunct: 1 mL of neomycin-polymyxin B sulfate irrigation solution added to 1000 mL of NS for continuous bladder irrigation over 24 hours; if urine output greater than 2 L/day, inflow rate adjusted to deliver 2000 mL over a 24-hour period; length of treatment is up to 10 days
  • Meningitis: 50,000 units INTRATHECALLY once daily for 3 to 4 days, then 50,000 units intrathecally every other day for at least 2 weeks after cerebrospinal fluid cultures are negative and sugar content has returned to normal

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
• Intramuscular (Powder for Solution)
    Polymyxin B sulfate should be given only to hospitalized patients when administered IM and/or intrathecally. Therapy has been associated with potential neurotoxicity and nephrotoxicity. Monitor renal function during therapy and reduce dose in patients with renal impairment. Concurrent use of other neurotoxic or nephrotoxic agents should be avoided. Neuromuscular blockade and respiratory paralysis can occur following administration, especially when the drug is given soon after anesthesia and/or muscle relaxants. The safety of this drug in pregnancy has not been established.
  • Intrathecal (Powder for Solution)
    Polymyxin B sulfate should be given only to hospitalized patients when administered IM and/or intrathecally. Therapy has been associated with potential neurotoxicity and nephrotoxicity. Monitor renal function during therapy and reduce dose in patients with renal impairment. Concurrent use of other neurotoxic or nephrotoxic agents should be avoided. Neuromuscular blockade and respiratory paralysis can occur following administration, especially when the drug is given soon after anesthesia and/or muscle relaxants. The safety of this drug in pregnancy has not been established.
  • Intravenous (Powder for Solution)
    Polymyxin B sulfate should be given only to hospitalized patients when administered IM and/or intrathecally. Therapy has been associated with potential neurotoxicity and nephrotoxicity. Monitor renal function during therapy and reduce dose in patients with renal impairment. Concurrent use of other neurotoxic or nephrotoxic agents should be avoided. Neuromuscular blockade and respiratory paralysis can occur following administration, especially when the drug is given soon after anesthesia and/or muscle relaxants. The safety of this drug in pregnancy has not been established.

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant or sequential use of curariform muscle relaxants or other neurotoxic or nephrotoxic drugs, particularly bacitracin, streptomycin, neomycin, kanamycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin, cephaloridine, paromomycin, viomycin, or colistin; avoid use
  • intramuscular or intrathecal administration; constant supervision required; administer only to hospitalized patients
  • nephrotoxicity, may occur; usual symptoms include azotemia, cellular casts, and albuminuria; discontinuation may be required if decreased urine output and rising BUN are observed
  • neurotoxic reactions manifested by irritability, weakness, drowsiness, ataxia, perioral paresthesia, numbness of the extremities, or blurring of vision may occur; increased risk in patients with renal impairment or nephrotoxicity
  • renal damage and nitrogen retention; dose reductions recommended
  • respiratory paralysis may occur; increased risk with administration following anesthesia or muscle relaxants; discontinuation required
  • Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea, including mild diarrhea to fatal colitis, has been reported; may occur up to 2 months after antibiotic therapy; if suspected or confirmed, discontinuation may be required
  • superinfection may occur

sub.mono: Polymyxin B: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Polymyxin B: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Polymyxin B sulfate is a basic polypeptide antibiotic that has bactericidal activity against nearly all strains of gram-negative bacilli, except those of the Proteus group. It exerts its effect by increasing bacterial cell membrane permeability leading to death of the cell. It is not effective against gram-positive bacteria, fungi, or gram-negative cocci.

1.title: Distribution
1.mono:
• Protein binding: 78.5% to 92.4%, critically ill subjects; 55.9%, healthy subjects
  • Vd: 71 to 194 mL/kg (critically ill subjects)

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Renal: 0.04% to 4.04% unchanged
  • Renal clearance: 0.00032 to 0.0039 mL/min/kg; 0.061 L/hr
  • Total body clearance: 0.27 to 0.81 mL/min/kg; 0.0276 L/hr/kg

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    refrigerate parenteral products after preparation and use within 72 hours
  • Intramuscular
    • not routinely recommended because of severe pain
    • dissolve 500,000 units in 2 mL of sterile water for injection, NS, or procaine hydrochloride 1% injection
  • Intrathecal
    dissolve 500,000 units in 10 mL of NS (final concentration 50,000 units/mL)
  • Intravenous
    • dissolve 500,000 units in 300 to 500 mL of D5W; infuse as continuous drip
    • may be infused intermittently every 12 hours; infusion durations of 60 to 120 minutes have been well-tolerated in adults
  • Ophthalmic
    dissolve 500,000 units in 20 to 50 mL of sterile water for injection or NS (final concentration 10,000 to 25,000 units/mL or 0.1% to 0.25%)

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement or reduction in fever may indicate efficacy
  • CBC normalization may indicate efficacy
  • (injection) renal function; baseline and frequently during parenteral therapy
  • (injection) blood levels of the drug; baseline and frequently during parenteral therapy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of nephrotoxicity.
  • Patient should report signs/symptoms of neurotoxicity, especially when given soon after anesthesia or muscle relaxants.
  • Instruct patient on proper instillation technique.
  • Patients using ophthalmic preparation should not use any other eye drops or medications unless approved by healthcare professional.
